pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Kosambī in Ghosita’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:1.6: and he just did it again out of disrespect.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:1.7: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:1.9: “Is it true, Channa, that you’re acting disrespectfully?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:1.12: “… Foolish man, how can you act disrespectfully?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:1.13: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:1.14: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:1.15.1: ‘If a monk is disrespectful, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.1.2: there are two kinds of disrespect: disrespect for the person and disrespect for the rule.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.1.4: if, when he is corrected by one who is fully ordained about a rule that has been laid down, he thinks, “They’ve been ejected,” “They’ve been reproved,” “They’ve been censured,” and then, “I won’t do what they say,” and he acts disrespectfully, then he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.1.6: if, when he is corrected by one who is fully ordained about a rule that has been laid down, he thinks, “What can be done so that this rule is lost or perishes or disappears,”or he does not want to train in that rule, and he acts disrespectfully, then he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.1: If the other person is fully ordained, and he perceives them as such, and he acts disrespectfully, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.2: If the other person is fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, and he acts disrespectfully, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.3: If the other person is fully ordained, but he does not perceive them as such, and he acts disrespectfully, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.4: If he is being corrected about something that has not been laid down—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.5: “This isn’t conducive to the erasing of defilements,” “This isn’t conducive to ascetic practices,” “This isn’t conducive to being inspiring,” “This isn’t conducive to a reduction in things,” “This isn’t conducive to being energetic”—and he acts disrespectfully, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.6: If he is being corrected by one who is not fully ordained, whether or not it has been laid down—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.7: “This isn’t conducive to the erasing of defilements,” “This isn’t conducive to ascetic practices,” “This isn’t conducive to being inspiring,” “This isn’t conducive to a reduction in things,” “This isn’t conducive to being energetic”—and he acts disrespectfully, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.8: If the other person is not fully ordained, but he perceives them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.9: If the other person is not fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.2.10: If the other person is not fully ordained, and he does not perceive them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.3.2: if he says, “This is how we were taught and tested by our teachers;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.3.4: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc54:2.3.5: The fourth rule, the training rule on disrespect, is finished.
